articles.title: Study: Warming of world's oceans accelerating

articles.summary: The world's oceans were warmer in 2024 than at any time since measurements began. The record applies to both surface temperatures and the heat stored at a depth of 2,000m. The oceans play an important role in the Earth's climate, absorbing around 90 percent of the heat generated by rising seas.

articles.title: 2024 was the warmest year on record
articles.author: George Lee
articles.summary: Last year was the warmest on record. The average global temperature was between 1.55 and 1.6 degrees Celsius above pre-industrial levels. The oceans absorb 90% of the extra heat trapped on Earth because of the higher concentrations of greenhouse gases. The amount of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere is already 50% higher than before the age of oil. There is more carbon dioxide floating in Earth's atmosphere now than at any point over the past 2 million years. Methane has a more powerful global warming impact than carbon dioxide.

articles.title: World must act fast on climate following warmest year

articles.title: 2024 was warmest year on record for mainland US, says new report
articles.summary: 2014 was the hottest year on record in the lower 48 states and Washington. It was the third-wettest since 1895 and the second-highest number of tornadoes on record. President-elect Donald Trump has pledged to expand fossil fuel production and roll back green policies.

articles.title: Grimsby scientist named to Order of Canada renowned for researching contaminated Indigenous food supply in the Arctic

articles.title: Grimsby scientist named to Order of Canada renowned for researching contaminated Indigenous food supply in the Arctic

Human-caused climate change has caused hydroclimate whiplash to increase by 31 to 66 per cent globally. A deadly blaze destroyed 32 homes during October 2023 in Queensland. The next month, nearby weather stations recorded their highest-ever November rainfall. Professor David Bowman has called for a rethink of urban fire risk.

articles.summary: Temperatures rose more than 1.5 degrees Celsius above preindustrial levels during the hottest year on Earth since records began in 1850, according to the World Meteorological Organization.       in the last 12 months. In the last year, it was the warmest year since 1850.

articles.title: 2024 hottest year ever, crossed 1.5 global warming limit
articles.author: Urdu Point
articles.summary: The last two years saw average temperatures exceed a critical warming limit for the first time. The UN has demanded "trail-blazing" climate action. However, it does not mean the internationally-agreed international warming limit will be met.

articles.title: 2024 first year to pass 1.5C global warming limit
articles.author: BBC News
articles.summary: Last year was the world's warmest on record, bringing temperatures above a symbolic milestone, according to the UN's World Meteorological Agency. It was also the hottest year on record for the whole of the world, except for a few isolated pockets.

articles.title: FLASH: 2024 CONFIRMED TO BE WARMEST YEAR ON RECORD GLOBALLY -- COPERNICUS
articles.author: Xinhua
articles.summary: 2024 confirmed to be the warmest year on record globally.   Â   in the world. It will be warmer than in 2024 than in any other year in the history of the world so far, according to the report.

articles.title: Greenland eyes the benefits in Trump's proposed land grab
articles.author: Japan Times
articles.summary: Greenland's geopolitical importance is rising as its ice sheet melts. It is expected to be a key part of global shipping routes as the ice sheet thaws and Greenland becomes a more important destination for shipping routes.    i.e. it's expected to play a key role in global shipping.

articles.title: 2024 becomes warmest year on record, 1st to breach 1.5 deg C guardrail
articles.author: The Economic Times
articles.summary: In 2024, global temperatures reached a record high, averaging 1.5 degrees Celsius above pre-industrial levels. The year also saw a rise in global sea levels by 1.3 degrees Celsius.       in sea levels rose by 0.5 degree Celsius.

articles.title: How to cope with climate anxiety, according to experts and studies
articles.author: Manila Bulletin
articles.summary: "Climate anxiety" is a chronic worry and distress about climate change. Managing it involves integrating awareness, action and community support into our everyday routines. It also involves recognizing the reality of climate change and its related anxieties while embracing our ability to effect change through sustainable practices.

articles.title: Earth has entered ‘a new era' with its hottest year on record
articles.author: The Times/The Sunday Times
articles.summary: Last year was the hottest on record. For the first time, temperatures were 1.5C warmer than before the Industrial Revolution. The UK and nearly 200 countries promised to hit the target of 1.3C warming in the Paris climate accord.

articles.title: Last 2 years crossed 1.5C global warming limit: EU monitor
articles.author: LUIS TATO
articles.summary: The last two years have exceeded on average a critical warming limit for the first time. This does not mean the internationally-agreed 1.5C warming threshold has been permanently breached, but the Copernicus Climate Change Service said it was drawing dangerously near.

articles.title: 2024 hottest recorded year, crossed global warming limit
articles.author: LUIS TATO
articles.summary: The last two years saw average temperatures exceed a critical warming limit for the first time in Europe's climate monitor. This does not mean the internationally-agreed 1.5C warming threshold has been permanently breached, but the UN warns it is in "grave danger".

articles.title: Uruguay bucks 2024 global warming trend
articles.author: Eitan ABRAMOVICH
articles.summary: Last year was the warmest globally since data recording began in 1850, according to Europe's climate monitor Copernicus. However, in Uruguay, global warming was counteracted by bouts of "near-historic" cold.   Javascript is required to be able to read premium content.

articles.title: Earth records hottest year ever in 2024 and the jump was so big it breached a key threshold
articles.author: Seth Borenstein
articles.summary: Earth recorded its hottest year ever in 2024. Last year's global average temperature easily passed 2023's record heat. July 10 was the hottest day recorded by humans, with the globe averaging 17.16 degrees Celsius (62.89 degrees Fahrenheit). The last 10 years are the 10 hottest on record and are likely the hottest in 125,000 years. The biggest contributor to record warming is the burning of fossil fuels.

articles.title: Cold weather can be good for some business
articles.author: Gordon Jackson
articles.summary: Winter has just started in the Golden Isles. Businesses are busier than normal for this time of year. articles.title: Apocalyptic LA wildfire nightmare our new collective climate change doom-loop future
articles.author: Martyn Bradbury
articles.summary: ACT, NZF and National are Climate Fascists who bend over backwards for the interests of the polluters. The political class and corporate class continue to water down environmental legislation. As the speed of climate change hits us, as the true cost of our denial is realised, protestors will get angrier and angrier at the inaction.

articles.title: Ndawanifa encourages farmers to take advantage of good rainfall
articles.author: Namibian Sun
articles.summary: Ohangwena regional council chairperson Erickson Ndawanifa urges subsistence farmers in northern Namibia to seize the opportunity presented by the promising rainfall this season. Kenya Kambowe is a subsistence farmer in the area. He lives in Kambowo.
